moves.1. d4 d5 2. Bf4 e6 3. Nf3 Bd6: Ok, standard constes of the center.
moves.4. Qd2: Other options are Bg3, Ne5 or BxB.
moves.4... Bxf4 5. Qxf4: My queen is already out, joined with a knight, while black is undeveloped. Almost a death sentence.
moves.6... O-O: The risky defensive castling has to be covered with pieces...
moves.7. e3: This "innocent" move opens the way for the lsb.
moves.7... c6: This innocent move just accomplish nothing. Black had to try to exchange queens.
moves.9... g5: Done. The game is won. This is exactly what you should never do. This same pattern presents itself in a lot of games, normally with a more complicate structure, where things are not so easy like here. But you can take this as a reference for your games, any time you plan the "double kick sequence". Both as attacker or defender...
